commander.name: General Arnaldo Azzi
commander.previous_service: Commanded division since August 1942 through final battles in Tunisia

supply_logistics.supply_status: Critical - Division retreating from Libya to Tunisia after El Alamein defeat. Supply lines stretched over 1800km from Tripoli. Fuel and ammunition severely limited. Division maintained cohesion during retreat but suffered heavy attrition.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Tunisia - mixed coastal plains, hills, and mountainous terrain (Dorsale Mountains)

tactical_doctrine.role: Assault and Landing Division - Specialized in combined operations, amphibious assaults, and mountain warfare. Trained at Leghorn (Italian combined operations center) and Gaeta. One of only three Italian assault divisions (with 4th Livorno and 20th Friuli).
special_capabilities: Decentralized heavy weapons (battalion-level control vs regimental)
tactical_innovations: Heavy weapons moved from regimental to battalion control
Light weapons moved from battalion to company control
known_issues: Inadequate anti-tank capabilities against Allied armor
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Division had extensive North Africa experience since mid-1942. Adapted to desert warfare but specialized assault/landing capabilities less relevant in desert terrain. Retreat from Libya to Tunisia degraded unit cohesion and equipment strength.

scenario_suitability: Italian infantry defense against Allied advances
historical_engagements: Second Battle of El Alamein (October 23 - November 11, 1942)

source: US Army Order of Battle of the Italian Army, July 1943 (pages 25-26, assault division description)
Nafziger Collection file 942IFBA: 1st Superga Division, North Africa, 15 June 1942
National Archives Microcopy No. T-821, Roll 144

personnel_1943q1.reason: Only June 1942 data available from Nafziger. 1943-Q1 estimated based on 60% combat effectiveness after El Alamein losses and retreat attrition.
sources_checked: US Army G2 Italian Army OOB July 1943
personnel_1943q1.mitigation: Search Italian military archives or captured documents for 1943 quarterly returns
personnel_1943q1.estimate_method: Applied 60% combat effectiveness multiplier to June 1942 baseline (4,492 troops â†’ ~8,500 with full division). Accounts for El Alamein casualties and retreat attrition.

vehicle_counts.reason: June 1942 data shows 60 trucks for 92nd Regiment only. Full divisional vehicle strength estimated based on Italian assault division TO&E.
sources_checked: US Army G2 Italian Army manual
vehicle_counts.estimate_method: Italian assault division standard: ~250-300 vehicles. Reduced by 40% for retreat losses.

commander_details.reason: Gen. Azzi confirmed as final commander, but exact appointment date uncertain. Estimated August 1942.
sources_checked: US Army G2 Italian Army OOB
commander_details.mitigation: Verify Italian Army command records for exact appointment date

exact_destruction_date.reason: US Army OOB confirms destruction in Tunisia 1943, but specific date (likely May 1943 during final Axis collapse) not documented in sources reviewed.
sources_checked: US Army G2 Italian Army OOB July 1943

notes: Superga Division was one of only 3 Italian Assault and Landing Divisions (with 4th Livorno and 20th Friuli)
Division trained for combined operations at Leghorn and mountain warfare at Castelforte
Reorganized in 1941 with decentralized support weapons for independent small-unit operations
Fought at Second Battle of El Alamein (October-November 1942) - suffered heavy casualties
Retreated from Libya to Tunisia (November 1942 - January 1943)
Destroyed in Tunisia Campaign (May 1943) per US Army Intelligence
June 1942 data from Nafziger shows: 91st Regiment (34 officers, 1,054 troops), 92nd Regiment (122 officers, 3,438 troops)
1943-Q1 data is extrapolated from June 1942 baseline with 60% effectiveness adjustment for combat losses
